STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
December 10, 2024
Linda Sue Needham
Lenawee County DHHS
1040 S Winter ST,
Adrian, MI, 49221-3876
Re: License #: CP460201242
Dear Ms. Needham:
Attached is the Amended Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency
completed on 11/1/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written
corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date
of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 899-6024.
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
AMENDED
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION

Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services

Chief Administrator: Linda SUE Needham
Name of Agency: LENAWEE COUNTY DHHS

ADRIAN, MI 49221-3876
Agency Telephone #: 5172646300
Original Issuance Date: 06/01/1992

Applicants for adoption, Place children for
adoption, Place children in foster home,
Supervise Independent Living
1

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12208 Job descriptions.
(1) An agency shall have a current written job description
for each staff and position.
One of one new staff records reviewed did not show documentation of a job
description for the person listed as an Intern.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record must contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(d) Three references obtained from persons who are
unrelated to the staff person.
One of one new staff records reviewed did not show documentation of three
references.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up to
the time of the change in placement and the needs that
remain to be met.
2

Two of four closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (a)
as required by the rule. The information was left blank.
Repeat Violation Established
Renewal 2023 CAP approved 10/12/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
Two of four closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (b)
as required by the rule. The information was left blank.
Repeat Violation Established.
Renewal 2023 CAP approved 10/12/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(i) A comprehensive medical examination, including a
behavioral/mental health and trauma screening, within
30 calendar days from the date the child entered into an
out-of-home placement, regardless of the date of the last
physical examination.
One of six open foster child records reviewed showed the child’s trauma screen due
by 7/5/2024 was completed late on 7/18/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
3

One of six open foster child records reviewed showed the child's initial service plan
was completed16 days late.
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(a), must include all the following
information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R 400.12404(4).
One of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of(c).
This information was left blank.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R400.12326(1) Borrowed Home:
• The agency was apprised documentation of the foster parent’s willingness to
accept the child shall be consistently documented for both foster parents in a
two-parent foster home.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Nothing this inspection.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted two corrective action plans(CAP) this reporting period.
The first corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2023 Renewal Inspection
where it received 11 rule violations. Nine of those citations were rule related; and
two related to state policies. This year the agency received seven rule violations,
of which two were repeat citations from 2023. The agency made progress on the
corrective action plan, as noted from the inspection review. The agency plans to
address the repeat violation in this years CAP.
4

The second corrective action plan related to Special Investigation
2024C0001092SI. This invesigation related to a complaint received on 1/26/2024,
which alleged the case manager did not provide case management as required
per the rule and that service plans were not completed timely. The agency was
found in violation of R400.12207(3)(b) for Staff responsiblities and
R400.1218(2)(b) for Development of service plans. The agency submitted an
acceptable corrective action plan on 3/4/2024. A review of this CAP on 9/11/2024
and again during this inspection showed the agency has completed this corrective
action plan.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator (CA) submitted a chief administrator’s report dated
10/29/2024. The CA reported barriers to consistent rule compliance tended to be
related to workers not consistently following the steps in job aids and policy. The
CA reported staff and supervisory reviews when consistent, has allowed for
successes in rule compliance. Additionally, that the agency has found, via its
random case audits, that the agency has made progress on its CAP. That DHS-
69s cited last year for change of placement documentations are being completed
and its CAP on medicals and dentals has been effective. That its coordination
between workers, the caregivers, and the health liaison officer made a positive
impact on them achieving compliance in this area. The CA reported the agency
will continue to review policy/rule requirements with staff on an ongoing basis.
Financial Overview
This is a Department of Health and Human Services agency. No financial
documentation is required.
Staff Interviews
In addition to discussion with the chief administrator, a section manager and three
supervisors, three foster care workers, and one licensing worker were interviewed.
The staff interviewed reported support from coworkers and managerial staff, good
communication during staff meetings, and that their supervisor and the director will
reach out to praise them. Areas of growth reported related to some supervisors
needing to be more consistent with scheduled supervisions, more worker
checklists to aid and educate workers so that required things/tasks are not missed,
and continued appreciation and understanding from management about the
stresses on foster care workers and the challenges of the job.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the agency’s office did not reveal any areas of concern. There
was sufficient space and equipment for staff and files were secure. The agency
has gone paperless, and files/documents are electronically stored.
VII. CHILD PLACING AGENCY ANALYST FINDINGS
There were three safety alerts.
5

Alert # 1- Notification reported 8/7/2024.
Concern:
The Division of Child Welfare (DCWL) Analyst was unable to connect with the caregiver
for a scheduled home visit that had been rescheduled. On the day of the rescheduled
visit, the caregiver reported she was feeling ill, and if she was not better by the time for
the home visit she would contact the Analyst. The Analyst attempted to confirm the visit
an hour ahead, and there was no answer/reply by the caregiver. The DCWL Analyst
was unable to verify the welling of the foster children in the home.
Resolution:
The agency made a home visit to the caregiver’s home on 8/8/2024 and verified the
wellbeing of the children, and safety of the home. No concerns were indicated in the
agency’s response.
Alert # 2- Notification reported 8/7/2024.
Concern:
The DCWL Analyst had a home visit with the caregiver scheduled for 8/7/2024; and
when she arrived at the home, no one answered the door or phone. The DCWL Analyst
was unable to verify the welling of the foster child in the home.
Resolution:
The agency made a home visit to the caregiver’s home on 8/8/2024 and verified the
wellbeing of the child and safety of the home. Other than the worker noting that the
child’s room was in need of cleaning, no concerns with the child or home safety
concerns were indicated.
Alert # 3 - Report
Concern:
The DCWL Analyst was unable to connect with the unlicensed relative after five
attempts between 8/12/2024 and 8/21/1024 via either email, text or phone. The Analyst
was unable to verify the welling of the child in the home.
Resolution:
The agency attempted a home visit with the caregiver by way of an on-call worker on
8/26/2024 without success. The assigned worker made a home visit with the caregiver
on 8/27/2024. The wellbeing of the child, and safety of the home was verified at that
time. No concerns were indicated.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
6

December 10, 2024
